issue.title: Doesn't work with shared examples
issue.body:
I don't believe this is a problem of respec, but of rspec itself.

I created an issue here:

https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/issues/793

If they don't think about changing it, what could be done on your side?

Thanks for this very useful gem.

body:
I have created a fix for respec.

https://github.com/oggy/respec/pull/3/files

The formatter now looks through the `example.metadata` hash until it finds the first `location` that is a `..._spec.rb` file. This is used, instead of simply the first `location`.

Maybe it would make sense to apply a mechanism like this for the default formatter, too?
Seems like a reasonable approach, however it should probably be based on `RSpec.configuration.pattern` so it works even when users change that to something like `"**/*.spec"`.
`RSpec.configuration.pattern` ? Can you explain this a bit further? Maybe with pseudo code. :+1:

See http://rubydoc.info/gems/rspec-core/RSpec/Core/Configuration#pattern-instance_method

RSpec treats files matching this glob pattern as spec files. The default is `"spec/**/*_spec.rb"`, but you can override that via `RSpec.configure` or the command line `--pattern` option, so rather than [using a literal as you currently do](https://github.com/oggy/respec/pull/3/files#L0R12), it'd be better to use the value of `RSpec.configure.pattern`.

Ah I get it now! I'll apply this.

Is there a chance that something like this will find its way into the RSpec core? So all formatters would print the `xxx_spec.rb` line even for shared examples?
I think it's a good idea. @myronmarston WDYT?
Hm any idea on how to create a regexp from `RSpec.configuration.pattern`?
Ugh. Good point. /me puts on thinking cap ...

This has bugged me before as well, but I hadn't really given thought to how we might change it....so I'm glad to see this discussion taking place.  A few thoughts:
- It's also bugged me that the "shared example group called from" output is limited to one level.  In cases where you have nested shared example groups, it'd be nice if the whole "shared example call stack" was displayed.
- Once we get that call stack in place exposed from the metadata, this becomes far easier--you can just walk up that call stack to the original entry point to shared examples (e.g. the top-level `it_behaves_like` in a spec file).
- That said, bear in mind that if you re-run the specs passing that line number, it'll run all of the shared examples, and not just the failing one. 

> Is there a chance that something like this will find its way into the RSpec core? So all formatters would print the xxx_spec.rb line even for shared examples?

Yep, I'd like to fix things so that any formatters which use `dump_commands_to_rerun_failed_examples` include the originating line for the use of the shared example group.
I'm happy to see that I could start a serious discussion about this. Let me know if I can be of any more help. :+1:
Is there anything going on about this topic?
Not yet.  It's still an open issue to fix.  I've had more important things on my radar.

issue.title: Shared Examples: context prevents "it" blocks from being executed when trying to execute them using a line number
issue.body:
Just noticed that my shared examples' `it` blocks were not executed when I ran them with an exact line number like so:

`rspec spec/my_spec.rb:123`

But when I ran them as the whole file, the `it` blocks were executed as expected:

`rspec spec/my_spec.rb`

After some debugging, I found that my shared examples' `it` blocks were in a `context` block - when I removed them, I could successfully execute them using a line number.

Is this a known bug/feature? Should I avoid contexts in shared examples?

issue.title: Rerun failed spec with example groups in different files does not work.

repository.name: guard-rspec
repository.description: Guard::RSpec automatically run your specs (much like autotest)

issue.body:
The core issue is a rspec issue listed here https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/issues/793.

For example:

I have a shared_examples in  lib/my_shared_example.rb.  
I use this shared example in spec/lib/my_other_spec.rb.
And an expectation of this shared example groups fails,
then guard-rspec tries to execute the file lib/my_shared_example.rb
insteed of spec/lib/my_other_spec.rb.

I found 2 workarounds for this:

1st workaround:

Guardfile

``` ruby
 guard :rspec, failed_mode: :none do
```

2nd workaround:

spec_helper.rb

``` ruby
require 'guard/rspec'

# issue https://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/issues/793

module Guard
  class RSpec
    class Formatter
      def self.extract_spec_location(metadata)

        while !(metadata[:location] =~ /_spec.rb:\d+$/) do

          metadata = metadata[:example_group]
          raise 'No spec file could be found in meta data!' unless metadata

        end

        metadata[:location]
      end

      def _failed_paths
        failed = examples.select { |e| e.execution_result[:status] == 'failed' }
        failed.map { |e| extract_spec_location(e.metadata[:location]) }
      end
    end
  end
end
```

Is there a better way to fix this issue?

issue.title: shared examples in external file are not included
issue.body:
I have the following in an external file `spec/controllers/shared_examples/unauthorized.rb` 

``` ruby
shared_examples "unauthorized" do |action|
  context "when an unauthorized user is logged in" do
    login_user

    it "prevents access" do
      get action
      expect(response).to be_redirect
      expect(flash[:alert]).to_not be_nil
    end
  end
end
```

and I also have this in `spec_helper`

```
Dir[Rails.root.join("spec/support/**/*.rb")].each { |f| require f }
Dir[Rails.root.join("spec/models/shared_examples/**/*.rb")].each {|f| require f}
Dir[Rails.root.join("spec/controllers/shared_examples/**/*.rb")].each {|f| require f}
```

And in one of my controller specs I do:

```
describe "GET index" do
  include_examples "unauthorized", :index
end
```

And this is what I get: `0 examples, 0 failures`

gem 'rspec-rails', '~> 3.0.0.beta'

issue.title: Feature idea: new `--bisect` flag
issue.body:
The [minitest-bisect](https://github.com/seattlerb/minitest-bisect) project looks really useful for use on minitest-based projects.  I'd like to see something similar in RSpec.  It could be a separate gem (as it is for minitest) but I think it would fit well in rspec-core.  Bisect isn't a feature you normally need or use on an ongoing basis -- it's just when you suddenly hit an order dependency you didn't know you had that RSpec's random ordering has surfaced.  In such a situation, it's sub-optimal to have to install another gem, and you may not even be able to (such as if you run into this situation when you are offline).  Having it built in to rspec-core will keep it available when you need it without you having to plan ahead to have the gem available.

Ideally, the output of the `--bisect` flag would provide you with a command you can run to reproduce the failure with the smallest number of examples that triggers the error.  One thing that would help is a way to select specific examples from the command line.  We have the `-e` flag now that selects examples with matching doc strings, and we have the `file:line_number` syntax, but those are not workable solutions to selecting a specific examples in some situations. Consider that we allow multiple examples to be defined with the same doc string (ruling out `-e`) and the same line can define multiple examples, if you use a loop, ruling out `file:line_number`.  Instead, I was thinking we could introduce a new `--ids` option, which would take a form like:

``` ruby
rspec --ids 2:14,3:1:20,4:2:1:5
```

...which would run the 14th example defined in the 2nd example group, the 20th example from the first example group nested within the 3rd global example group, and the 5th example from the 1st group within the 2nd group within the 4th global example group.
